name: Scrappy Puppet Tales - Summer at MAP
description:
Summer holidays are here, and are the kids already chanting "I'm bored?"! Get them over to MAP for an exciting summer camp filled with art, learning and group activities facilitated by professional artists. Give your kids a summer to remember at the museum.

Get ready for some fun storytelling! In the Scrappy Puppet Tales workshop, kids will become puppet creators using all sorts of cool scrap and junk. It's a hands-on adventure where imagination takes center stage. Guided by renowned actress  and puppeteer Padmavati Rao, children will bring their wacky puppet characters to life. The grand finale? A showcase where each young artist gets to present their puppet creations!

Age group- 9-12 year olds. Registration fees is ₹1000. Number of participants are limited so please register to confirm your spot.

name: Training Course in Conservation of Photographs in Museums, Archives, and Collections
description:
Don’t let history disappear–or discolour–or fade! Discover the science of photography conservation and learn the art of restoring historic photograph collections. This hands-on, intensive training course is designed for practising conservators, archivists and custodians of historic photograph collections to learn preventive collection care measures, remedial conservation processes, and restoration techniques.

This three month course will be followed by a one month internship. The course will be instructed by leading specialists from India and overseas and includes topics such as: 

 -Development, materials and techniques of historic photographic processes

 -Identification and understanding of deterioration processes in photograph collections

 -Inspection and survey methodologies

 -Condition report preparation and preservation prioritisation decisions

 -Emergency treatment measures

 -Conservation of film and glass plate negatives

 -Conservation and restoration of photographs

 -Archival protocols of housing, display, and storage of photographic materials

 -Disaster management

Last day to apply: 25th May, 2025

Apply for this programme and we will let you know if you are selected by 31st May, 2025.

name: A Symphony of Movement
description:
Join us for a music performance by SUNADHA, the art and culture vertical of Samarthanam Trust for the Disabled. Ranging from soulful vocal renditions, to a prayer song accompanied by hand gestures, this performance features a band of people with exceptional talent.

For years, SUNADHA has captivated audiences worldwide, delivering over 3500 performances that have earned them acclaim. This is your chance to witness their artistry firsthand and experience the magic they create.

name: Art Conservation (11:30am)
description:
Art conservation is one of the most essential processes in a museum. From delicate cleaning, to the repair of sculptures and correction of minor painting damage, it ensures these cultural treasures endure.

In this lecture demonstration, you will be introduced to many of the conservation techniques used in museums. Led by the MAP Conservation Team, learn the science behind art conservation and gain valuable insights into how to protect and prolong the life of your own treasured items.

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming. 

You can also attend this event at 12:30pm.

name: Tuesday Tidbits
description:
Why is a sketch of a mother and child titled Wounds? Why is Venus segmented, and surrounded by an odd assortment of things? Find out the answers to these questions and more, at the upcoming Tuesday Tidbits led by Aayati Sengupta, the content and community coordinator from the MAP Marketing and Communications team.

Tuesday Tidbits is a series that explores different aspects of working in a museum through the lens of our team members. Join us for these free, insightful, and short sessions on life in a museum. 

This is part of our series that seeks to support youth in career research/building and acts as a space for networking for young people.

name: Art Conservation (12:30pm)
description:
Art conservation is one of the most essential processes in a museum. From delicate cleaning, to the repair of sculptures and correction of minor painting damage, it ensures these cultural treasures endure.

In this lecture demonstration, you will be introduced to many of the conservation techniques used in museums. Led by the MAP Conservation Team, learn the science behind art conservation and gain valuable insights into how to protect and prolong the life of your own treasured items.

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming. 

You can also attend this event at 11:30am.

name: Sketch with PencilJam
description:
If you enjoy drawing patterns or observational sketching, this session is for you. Join us for a relaxed, creative experience sketching around the museum space. Connect with fellow art lovers, find inspiration in the exhibits, and share your work in a friendly, informal setting. 

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

 

You’ll need to carry your own:

-Sketchbook or A4 paper

-Pencil (wood or mechanical) and eraser

-Gel pens or fineliners for outlining

-Colour brush pens, sketch pens, or colour pencils (no wet media)

name: The Mural Of The Story-Summer at MAP
description:
Summer holidays are here, and are the kids already chanting "I'm bored?"! Get them over to MAP for an exciting summer camp filled with art, learning and group activities facilitated by professional artists. Give your kids a summer to remember at the museum.

Learn about the art of mural painting, what goes on behind the planning of a mural, famous mural artists, etc. Facilitated by artist Deepa Juliana and inspired by the works of Bhuri Bai, kids will discover the fascinating process behind creating these large-scale artworks. Children will also get to paint their own mural at MAP! And the best part? We'll provide all the colours, brushes, and everything else they need to bring their vision to life.

So join this workshop and make this summer a colourful and creative one!

Age group- 13-16 year olds. Registration fees is ₹1000. Number of participants are limited so please register to confirm your spot.

name: Give me a sign!
description:
This is your sign to learn Indian Sign Language! This International Museum Day, learn words in sign language related to museums, art, culture and more. 

Join our Indian Sign Language sessions for beginners hosted by Hardeep Singh and Madhur Arora from the MAP team. Connect with the deaf community, learn to communicate beyond words, and pick up a valuable skill. 

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

name: Chittara Art
description:
Did you know that chittara in Kannada translates to picture or design? This folk art has geometrical designs featuring everyday life, and is native to the Deevaru community in the Sagar district of Karnataka. Chittara folk art is practiced primarily by the women of the community. They use eco-friendly materials like ground rice paste for white colour, charred rice for black, powdered gurige seeds (Strobilanthes kunthiana) for yellow, and soil/earth for red. 

Learn more about this artform and create your own chittara inspired collage on handmade, recycled paper.

This event will be followed by a book launch.

Photo credits: CFRIA

name: Art Hopping
description:
If you are one of those who look at art and say, “Okay but what does this mean?”, then we have the perfect solution for you! This International Museum Day, play a game with us! Collect a green ID card from the reception which will have prompts related to selected artworks within the museum. Wearing this card signals your consent to connect with others wearing the same tag, sparking conversations and diverse perspectives of the artwork.

You can sign up for this event at our reception. This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

name: Artwork Label-Making
description:
When you see a fascinating painting that you want to know more about, it's almost instinctive to look to the side and find the label that explains it! Labels provide essential information about an exhibit, such as the artist's name, title of the work, date of creation, medium or materials used and collection or loan information.

In this workshop, participants get to create such descriptive labels for artworks in the exhibition Vaanyerum Vizhuthugal: Roots that Reach for the Sky. The exhibition's overarching themes of identity address complex topics such as caste histories, domestic violence, and queer identity, among others.

Learn to create detailed text that provides additional context and information about the exhibit, adding images, colours, and more.

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

name: Visual Storage
description:
Museums are like icebergs – what you see on display is just the tip! Dive deeper into our collection with a guided walk of our visual storage by Rayna Rocha from the MAP Collections team. Learn more about our MAP archives, and have a look a part of the treasures within our collection. In this session you can learn about the challenges of storage, the importance of conservation, and the surprising discoveries that await within our hidden spaces in the museum.

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

name: The Great Tikat Hunt
description:
It’s game time at Ticket Tika Chaap! Come and discover the art of Indo-British textile trademarks through riddles. This exhibition explores  textile labels, known as tikats (tickets), tikas or chaaps, and their art-historical and commercial significance, as perhaps the earliest forms of branding and advertisement, in the 19th and 20th century global colonial market.

Intricately designed, these labels carry nuanced stories within them. This is your chance to decode its narrative—the more clues you find, the closer you get to victory. 

This event is a part of the International Museum Day programming.

name: Up, Close & Centre
description:
In this session of Up, Close & Centre, Arnika Ahldag (Director - Curation & Exhibition at MAP) will elaborate on an artwork from MAP’s latest exhibition, Vaanyerum Vizhuthugal: Roots that Reach for the Sky.

Initially exhibited as part of the Chennai Photo Biennale 2024-2025, for MAP this is the first ever group exhibition dedicated to contemporary photography and lens-based practices. Curated by Jaisingh Nageswaran, Vaanyerum Vizhuthugal (translating to “Roots that Reach for the Sky”) brings together the works of twelve lens-based artists of Tamil origin who push the boundaries of photography and visual storytelling.

This is a drop-in session. There is no registration required.
